Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same federal law banning drug users from possessing guns, later pardoned by President Joe Biden.
The Supreme Court agreed to review the constitutionality of the federal law banning drug users from possessing guns on this date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision on the Hemani case by the end of June 2025, which will determine whether the federal gun prohibition for drug users violates the Second Amendment.

The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a previous decision in 2023 rejecting the government’s claim that habitual drug use justifies a gun ban, which led to the Trump administration appealing the ruling.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing guns, raising questions about whether such a restriction violates the Second Amendment.

The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a U.S.-Pakistani dual citizen, who was charged in 2023 with violating the law after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home, with prosecutors citing his habitual marijuana use.
The Trump administration defended the law, claiming habitual drug users pose a risk to public safety, particularly during police encounters while impaired.

The government also alleged that Hemani had connections to Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps and participated in a celebration of Qasem Soleimani’s life, though these claims are not directly tied to drug use or gun possession.
The 5th Circuit Court of Appeals previously ruled that such a ban must be historically grounded, and only applies to individuals under the influence at the time of arrest, not habitual users.

Hemani’s legal team argued that the historical justification for the law is weak and that nearly half of U.S. states now allow recreational marijuana use, implying a significant overlap between legal marijuana users and gun ownership.
Hunter Biden was previously convicted under the same law in 2024 and later pardoned by President Joe Biden, drawing attention to the controversy surrounding the law’s application.
This case is part of a broader constitutional debate about the scope of the Second Amendment and whether modern laws restricting gun access based on drug use are constitutionally valid.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing firearms, focusing on whether such a restriction violates the Second Amendment. The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistani citizen charged in 2023 with possessing marijuana and cocaine at his home, with prosecutors citing his habitual use. The Trump administration defended the law, claiming habitual drug users pose a public safety risk, including during encounters with police. However, the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals previously ruled that such a ban must have historical roots, only applying to those under the influence at arrest, not habitual users. Hemani's legal team countered that the law's historical foundation is weak, especially given that nearly half of U.S. states now allow recreational marijuana use. The case is notable because it includes a similar precedent where Hunter Biden was convicted under the same law and later pardoned by President Joe Biden, highlighting the law’s political and social controversy. The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision by the end of June 2025.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
